newsitem.title: UK: Storehouse says Q1 sales up 14.5 pct.
newsitem.headline: Storehouse says Q1 sales up 14.5 pct.

text.p: British retailer Storehouse Plc said on Thursday that sales for continuing businesses were 14.5 percent higher in the first quarter than last year.
An additional seven weeks' trading by Childrens World, which was bought in May last year, accounted for 5.3 percent of the increase.

Storehouse said that underlying trend of sales and profitability were in line with its expectations and that both clothing and houseware retailer BHS and children's-wear chain Mothercare are showing like-for-like growth.
Excluding the seven week contribution from Childrens World, the combined sales at Mothercare and Childrens World grew 10.8 percent in the first quarter, while sales at BHS were 8.5 percent stronger.

Chairman Alan Smith told shareholders at the company's annual meeting that the last year had been "far from satisfactory" in terms of shareholder value as the company's share price was lower than last year.
"If we achieve what I believe our businesses are capable of achieving, I have little doubt that our success will be reflected before long in the share price," Smith said.
By 1137 GMT, shares in Storehouse had risen 13p to 201.
